segments.text: and looking at Shirley Turner's dissertation, and there was a Swiss scientist, Giovanoli.
Giovanoli spent his life studying, he's a chemist, studying manganese oxides.
He's considered sort of the dean of manganese oxides.
in that part of the world.
And he said Totorochite didn't exist.
And it was awful hard to settle that argument.
So this Sri Lankan student that I had, a postdoc really, who was working with me on different projects, I said one day we ought to try to synthesize some
and some other manganese oxides.
And within a year, I think, we had synthesized totorokite.
No one had ever done that before.
We published that in Science.
in, I don't know, 83 years, or a number of years ago, I'll say.
And since then, the industry's been interested in Todoroki.
And I've had interviews with some of them.
It's a big open structure, kind of like these pictures you're drawing here.
And there's water in the tunnels.
And they wanted to make a battery out of it.
When I was at Arizona State, the reason they were studying manganese oxide is because these little batteries that I wear in my ears here, they are probably manganese oxide batteries.
Many small button-sized batteries have manganese oxides in them.
But the chemistry of those manganese oxides and the structural chemistry is not well understood.
Todoroki was considered by the industry, and they published on it, but they never developed a battery from it.
Well, we went on, and in addition, we got good cooperation from the Swiss scientist Giovanni Olli.
He said it's his work.

and we synthesized other manganese oxides and then we identified them in soils from the Brazos River bottom and in other soils and they are still an area of sort of the forefront of our mineralogy because the crystals are so poorly formed and so difficult to analyze but yet
Now more recently, I was finishing up a student, a Korean student, who's now gone back to Korea.
And this is a twist in terms of research.
had a Canadian student in class, and one morning when he was in, before the offices were open, he got this phone call.

And this was someone from a drilling fluid company in Houston who said, we want to talk to someone that knows about iron oxides because we want to use them in drilling fluid, because we want to drill a new oil well
in a place where there isn't, it was an oil well once before, but it's failed, on the tidal zone of Louisiana, just across the line into Louisiana.
Would you be interested in that?
Well, he's a student, and he said, to give the information to me, he said, you might be interested in calling them back.
They gave us, I think it was $30,000 to do that project.
We knew all along
really what they needed to know about this iron oxide.
And what they wanted us to say was that they could use this iron oxide and it wouldn't create any environmental hazard there.
And they did some excellent work there.
They spent a lot of money, special equipment, to use hematite and recover the hematite because you could recover it.
It's a weighting material.
That's what adds to the density of the mass of this mixture of clay and iron oxide, in this case, to bring the rocks up out of the oil well.
And they normally use barite, but in the tidal zone, if the sulfate is reduced to sulfide, then that releases the barium, and the barium is a heavy metal, which is very toxic.
Well, when we got through with that part of it, we said, well, what else is in your drilling fluid?
Oh, we use some chromium humates.
Chromium?
Chromium is not a very friendly term.
It's another heavy metal.
And that student finished a certain part of that work on his dissertation, and I was desperate to support him, because he wanted to finish out more than that.
He'd gotten a lot of momentum.
Very diligent student, somewhat slow starter.
And so I called around, and Wayne Jordan in Water Resources said, call our new leader out in the GUSH Center.
His last name began with a Z, I think.
Anyway, he said he's trying to get some joint work going.
Maybe you could join together with him.
He could handle the policy side and you could handle the science side.
Ernie Vedlitz.
You may know him.
Ernie.
And I called Ernie and talked to him.
So I went out and we met him and took the student out.

And the upshot of it was that those soils that we studied in a post-doc jointly shared project, if they have manganese in them, manganese oxides in them, they will oxidize chromium and make it more soluble and mobile.
this local Brazos County soil has very little manganese in it, very, very little, and not much iron oxide.
It would be a great place to put waste drilling fluid.
Now that's not a kind of popular thing that people want to talk about because not exactly everybody wants somebody dumping their waste in their backyard, but we did find that
Some soils are very bad to put it in because that chromium may become soluble and enter into the groundwater.
And while we need a little chromium for our blood, for our sugar metabolism, we don't need very much.
And so that was one of my areas of interest, but grew out of these other.
Of all the research projects you've done, is there one that you're most proudest to claim?
Well, we were first to synthesize Todorokite.
Doug Ming's work on zeolites has grown into a lot.
Several of my colleagues have
worked with the Zeoponics thing and NASA and some here at A&M and some in other places in that development.
So you see, it's not my research really, it's mostly my students' research, is what it amounts to.
There are other areas even that are evolving now, but those are two of the highlights.
The manganese oxide.
See, there were several dominoes that had to fall to make that possible.
The sabbatical
the electron microscopy, the need for understanding chromium, and having the skills.
I'm particularly proud of that.
The work with the rice, we showed that there was ferrihydride in the soil where nobody else had done that before.
Dr. Monroe, one of the things I've concluded in my latter years is that those of us who work in these complex natural systems, we rarely solve all of a problem.
We usually bring forth our knowledge to solve part of the problem.
And we improve the technology and the science, but
We don't put it completely to rest very often.
But there's a lot of utility in what we do.
And just like that spinoff of NASA, you see, that obviously is very much outside of our expected area of contribution.
And I was thinking, of all the projects you've mentioned, a whole bunch of them were not necessarily agricultural.
Yes, that's right.
The funding for your work, did you get much outside funding or was by and large most of it through the experiment station?
I've had quite a lot of outside funding, although not as much as some others.
My area is a bit more basic, and it's more difficult for me to attack these funds that are attached to certain practical problems.
But the most funding probably was during the collaborative years with Hosner when we were working on mine spoil reclamation.
and that was recognized as a big problem area for the state.
And for about ten years we worked diligently on that and published papers and books in significant number.
Other major funders or fund sources?
Before I came, actually, I had an NSF grant for an instrument at Auburn.
And that contributed to my program there and contributed to my understanding of that method, which we have available today.
What are some of the honors that your teaching and research has brought?
Well, as you know,
I received the research award from the Alumni Association quite a number of years ago.
In the 70s, I think.
This is a different watch.
The first one wore out.
Really?
And mine's still going.
Well, you're kinder to it than I was with mine.
So it'll take me a few minutes to give you the.
Was it when we were still doing it secretly?
When you did, did you know it had been?
Yes, it was found secret.
And how did you feel that day?
Oh, I was, I will always remember that.
I was strangely impressed by the fact that the director of the Experiment Station, Neville Clark, seemed to be interested in sitting close to me.
I thought that was something kind of strange.
And that was a great day.
Now, of all the things, I was going to make some comments about administration.
That would be one of the positive comments I would make,
The awards program, these watch fobs are a very significant part of our recognizing people's success.
And I got an award in Washington for collaborative work with several people in the Reclamation area from the US Department of Agriculture.
Unfortunately, the Secretary of Agriculture, who gave it to us, was later convicted of crime.
which I think later was maybe rescinded.
But anyway, I'm still proud of the award.
I'm sorry we had some indiscretions there at some point.
Let me turn this off.
But the awards by the Former Students Association and then the awards in the more scientific professional areas by our own departments,
which are usually through national science organizations.
That is well developed at A&M.
My former department heads worked at it, and Runge was particularly adept at that.
And that's quite important.
A young faculty member has some
some apprehensions, and of course I came here as a professor, but then you kind of go through that when you're new anywhere.
And having an award system that kind of keeps people aware of what they do, and having another thing that we do here that's quite good, I think,
I don't know how much it's being pushed today, but we worked at it quite a bit.
And that is, whenever we get a new faculty member, we signed a mentor, at least one, to it.
And that's, you were talking about being accepted into the local culture, and that's very important, I think.
Did you ever think about leaving?
Oh, yes, yes, I have.
You know, different people have different views on their professions and what they want to do with them.
And why am I in Texas?
Well, some people would say one of the disadvantages of being at Texas A&M is we don't have any mountains, we don't have any lakes, at least not very many.
And the climate is just so-so.
But this is a good place to work with a lot of other people who like to work on creative things.
And the fact that we don't have to be bothered with the beach,
ten miles away or something, or even next door, and other distractions like that.
That's not a problem with me at all.
I enjoy what I do and have throughout my tenure here.
I would say, speaking for a moment on the social side of things,
The issues of the Bryan Eagle published this summer pointing up the fact that poverty is much higher in the abounding

surrounding counties than it is in Brazos County, which is certainly not new, but it really emphasized what I think is a concern of mine, and I think it's a concern that should be a bit more of the community.
And what research I'm going to try to accomplish within my next year, which may well be my last year of real active research, who knows,
I'm trying to address a bit of that.
In a sense, being given hard times, in a sense of being in a rather unspectacular environment, is a stimulus.
And it's been a great place.
It probably helps us to enjoy the people somewhat more.
For you and your family, what did you all do for joy, fun, diversion, satisfaction?
Very often with the family, we would go where I had formerly gone at a scientific meeting.
Because at a scientific meeting, I'm an outdoors kind of person.
almost always I'd go on a field trip.
And of course I would see some of the local culture even though I wasn't much involved.
Therefore, whenever I thought about where to go and the family had heard about the place, well that sounded like it might be a pretty interesting place to go.
And one of the attributes of this focal area of science that I work in, clay mineralogy,
is that there is a national organization that's not terribly large.
It's grown from perhaps 100 during my career up to maybe 500 or 600 or more at this stage.
And they can meet in some nice places.
Whereas the American Society of Agronomy, of course, is my bigger umbrella organization, they can only meet in big cities.
And so I have sort of been privileged to go to some very nice places.
And then my family and I have gone.
Sometimes they join me for the meetings, but oftentimes it's a follow through.
Do you have a hobby or hobbies?
Photography has always interested me, and I think taking pictures is probably the most of a hobby I have.
I enjoy, as a boy, I enjoyed fishing, and when I had sons that were in a fishing age, we fished as a family.
Where?
In Lake Somerville, and once to Trinity River Lake on the east of here, and occasionally in somebody's private pond.
But, and I have deer hunted a little bit, and I think my sons, perhaps one of them, has done a little of that.
But I, one has a different view on those kinds of activities here without knowing the landowners than what I had when I was a rural youth in western Kentucky.
So that changes the climate quite a bit.
Where you knew everybody.
Right.
We're going to start at the university and the college and the department.
How has Texas A&M changed, in your opinion, in these 30 plus years, for better or for worse?
Well, we have really wonderful facilities.
This university is, I think, an envy of many places.
And when I travel in the USA and other countries, we have some of the very nicest buildings.
We have some of the nicest remodeled buildings.
So we've got buildings that were
Some of them built quite a number of years ago, but they've been very well refurbished and are quite nice.
And we don't have buildings that we're ashamed of on the campus, I would say, which some universities struggle with that.
So I think that's one of our big assets here.
And the fact that we're growing, there's something about the momentum, the vigor that goes with growing.
Are we today as an institution making progress, you think?
I think we're making a lot of progress.
that we're, I like to dwell only on that, but I would like to just say that I think that we're struggling with how to deal with that song, and I don't know the answer to that.
But I think we need to step back and perhaps get out of our box completely and go to some quiet places for some small meetings and think about how to
to keep people more involved throughout their careers.
You've been able to teach throughout your career.
I think that's a great attribute.
And the interaction with students is very important.
And we should sustain that.
And I enjoy that.
I go to Mexico and teach a week every year for four years.
And I'll go again this year.
And they don't pay me money for that.
I work extra to do it, but I do it because I want to interact with the students and in, of course, a very different soils environment, so I learn quite a bit.
But even though they speak Spanish and I speak English, we have some interpreters and some of them speak pretty well in English.
And that's a great experience just to interact with eager
Some of them are more mature, some of them are professional already, and some of them are just in the senior year or so.
And the same thing in this country.

And so I think one of the frustrations I would say that seems inherent, and colleagues mention this to me more than any other, I don't hear much complaining, but one thing that is occasionally mentioned is,
We don't quite know how to interact with the administration.
And we have a high regard for our administration.
This institution has done really well to put in people that are sound people in principle.
And we have confidence in them.
But we don't quite know how to deal with communication up and down the administrative scale, as I perceive it.
I'm not going to ask the negative.
Of the presidents and the provosts and the deans that you've dealt with, which one, to which of those would you give the highest grades or highest rankings?
Who are the great presidents, provosts, deans?

Well, part of that is historically datable, I think, in a sense that Rudder has to be the greatest, but Rudder could not have necessarily been the greatest if he hadn't been here when the university was making great strides for him.
But we, as I see it, we chose a person, I don't know if you'd say it was a rebel, but a person who had somewhat revolutionary ideas and openness for this climate, and he had the respect of
of the old ags and the respect of others, so therefore he could go forward and people were pleased to follow, even though they may have disagreed with him on small points.
So I certainly have to hold him very high.
Any other presidents you'd give him?
I thought Williams was very scholarly, very much a person that we held in high regard.
I was never very close to him, didn't have much occasion to be, although he did attend the same church that I did as I recall.
And I certainly had a high regard for him.
My predecessor
George Coonsey, as a dean of the graduate school, I thought he was a good leader.
He knew where he stood, and he communicated well with us, and he understood our situation.
And I was sorry when he moved on, although he served his time well.
And he's still someone who I like to communicate with when I get a chance.
I have, as I mentioned to you, Kunkel as the dean was a good dean.
And Neville Clark, I thought, was a very good, not a particularly, I wouldn't say that Neville Clark was the kind of guy, if you took a poll, he'd get a popularity contest.
He's not quite that kind of personality.
But he was very, I learned Neville Clark when I was on the Electron Mic Committee, and they
ask him to monitor a decision on what that committee should be doing on some instrument or something.
And I found out right away that he was an exceptionally good diplomat.
And he was able to keep the committee going on a creative track in a reasonable time and not
get everybody at odds.
And that, I think, is a great attribute.
And so I thought he was a good leader, excellent leader.
I'm not much to raise anything but high marks for those administrators.
Are there some opportunities, either at departmental college or university level,
that you now in hindsight think that we missed?
Are there some things that we might have done that we didn't do?
Yes, I do.
I think two things that we could do.
One of them is research equipment.
As I told you earlier, I'm using the same x-ray machine that George Kunze used before me.
It was relatively new.
But I've been here for 30-plus years, and it would have been extremely difficult for me to get a new one.
Other instruments that we would like to have, we have not been able to get them very promptly.
And we've had to go and use them elsewhere.
You can do a lot with instruments in other locations.
But you sure can do a lot more if they're next door and you can be in with them daily.
And A&M needs to provide readily accessible basic research instruments.

Better as I view it and I know a lot of my colleagues would reflect that too I think sabbatical Needs more nurturing and it probably needs nurturing in in different ways in my case going away for I think ten and a half months and
That was great.
I made a little financial sacrifice, I guess, but I was able to get some support on the other end and get that together.
To really learn how to use the kind of instrument I wanted to use, I couldn't do it in a month or a few months because the book, the instrument was booked heavily.
I could only get on it so many hours a week.
And therefore, I had to sort of move along with everybody else.
And so having a long sabbatical of six months to a year is really important.
And I don't know how to... Another avenue that's kind of related to that.
In my work with the people in Mexico,
I find that they have a different cadence from what we do.
And I don't mean that in a critical way exactly.
They just have to deal with a different set of constraints.
And we really need interaction with these developing countries, Mexico in particular, I think.
And I have wanted to be able to bring those people in for short stints.
And they have come, some on their own,
But now that's expecting a whole lot.
And they could only stay like two weeks.
And I get some support within our experiment station this summer.
I got some support for a young woman to come for two weeks to finish up certain mineralogy on her thesis, which she's now finishing down there.
I think we need to have some flexibility in the comings and goings of our faculty for
Research and teaching.
And I think that it has to be, it should be more flexible to be more effective.
And there's just hardly anything that's more stimulating than changing environments.
All right, now in my hypothetical case, you are a consultant.
and you've been hired to give consulting advice to the department and to the college and to the university about its future.
What advice would you give to your department about what it should do?
To my department?
Mm-hmm.
In the future.
Introspective meeting.
with away from the local scene.
And now we've done some of this.
